entry.title: a little what if
entry.content:
Imagine if the genre of dubstep in all its global sprawl convened one day and came to total concensus tht it was just going to, well, stop.







I'm not saying that would be a good thing necessarily. But just imagine that for a second

entry.title: dubstep: the end as we know it?
entry.content:
a message was posted on www.dubstepforum.com last night about the annual awards... tucked innocuously away at the end of the message was this hugely significant little note:

And oh yes, weâ€™re also closing the forum. Indefinitely.

and that's it!

dubstep grew up with the forum (first at dubplate.net, then the new address), and the online atmosphere mirrored its tentative expansion, then its explosion in 2006, its eventual self-consciousness, and in the last year, its increasing sense of self-loathing.

while this sudden closure might be a bit of a fucker for some of the (count them) 20,000 members, especially those who relied on it for club listings, mixes, and so on, well - politically, this is a superb move.

in 2005, dubstep comprised a tight-knit web of djs, promoters, bloggers and enthusiasts, mostly (though not exclusively) based in london, mostly around the dmz and fwd>> club nights. this tight-knit web has been stretched and stretched by the many new and conflicting imperatives brought by the music's global success, to the point you now just have a big ugly woolly mess sprawled all over the floor. closing the forum will call time on this ugly mess, and call time on complacency. it will - we hope - force people to think forward again: where is their music going? what do they want it to become? where, in fact, are all the dubstep blogs at?

we at the spaz have had our share of beefs with 'the dubstep scene' and the forum (homogenous or not), but it certainly served a valuable purpose back in 2005, and hell, it pretty much made dubstep for a while. but now? now it's time to let the bass run free...

link.title: dubstep: the end as we know it?

entry.title: ghosts of pirate radio past
entry.content:
Meanwhile, a likkle 2step backwards. The website that dug deep to archive grime for future generations is getting a little formal recognition from a very informal radio station:

Tonight, www.grimetapes.com meets www.resonancefm.com downtown.

Dizzee and Wiley together on the FM dial again?!? Listen on 104.4FM in London, or online here, 8pm-9pm BST tonight in the 'Clear Spot'.

Keep checking back for details of "Wheel Vol. 1". If Grimetapes is Time Team for grime music, Wheel Vol. 1 should be like Tony Robinson grabbing a shank in both hands and going on a epileptic trashing-rampage through all of his Etruscan earthenware pots.

entry.title: pirate radio is back
entry.content:
Rinse heats up - and it's about time too.

But - first thing's first, I'd like to announce that international badderman Thomas O'C aka the Mr Dope Games will now be joining the Lower End Spasm fam. Kind of a backwards introduction, considering he already did his first post yesterday, but that's just how we do.


Now - Rinse. As Blackdown points out, following the weird lull in pirate sounds/vibes in recent times, London's airwaves are once again rich with flava.

Case in point: >Maximum b2b Spyro. (out to Elijah at Butterz where I downloaded this, and to Corpsey for the headsup.

Along with the recent Mak10 b2b Marcus Nasty set, I believe the above show represetns a phase shift in London pirate radio.
Maximum and Spyro play sick new grime tunes that kinda don't really sound like grime, mix them with bits of old skool, sped up funky, dubstep... it's across the board, experimental, unplanned and they bounce off each other with breathtaking effect.
We're almost back to that stage where we'd stuggle to define the overall sound of these sets.
Long live the spirit of exploratory mixing on Rinse!



EDIT:
(this isn't me shoehorning my own audio onto the end of a post about Rinse, honest. Just didn't want to hog the spotlight. )
For those that want it, Sub.FM archive audio of myself b2b Ben UFO of Hessle Audio from two weeks ago. It's kind of topical actually, as we mixed it up all across the board too:

Sub FM Night Slugs show 19.09.08 - Bok Bok b2b Ben UFO

tracklist in the comments>>

entry.title: Essential Afro Futurism
entry.content:
Dennis Ferrer does alot, he re-licked 'Cure & The Cause' to massive effect, has a list of releases going back over 10 years, as well as producing alongside Ibadan records founder Jerome Sydenham & remixing all n sundry. One thing he doesn't do tho, is bash his own tunes when he DJs, which is an anomaly in this day & age, something I have massive respect for.

His Essential Mix was filled to the brim with goodness! A HUGE remix of Sisters With Voices 'Rain', Ricky L â€˜Nothing Butâ€™ â€“ which is a big, BIG tune for me at the moment & â€˜Spells Of Yorubaâ€™ which I chucked in the short mix Bok Bok posted a little ways back.

The thing I love about Ferrer is that he has one foot in techy futurism & one foot planted firmly in the past, in acknowledging & building on ancient rhythms. His aesthetic is simultaneously earthy & chromed out, but not in a â€˜post industrialâ€™ or â€˜post apocalypticâ€™ way, not about self conscious darkness or dread vybez, more like using flint axes to get into space rather than being forced to cobble together fragments of lost technology.

Dennis is looking forward, into a future where we accept change that is out of our control, where instead of assuming we can assert our will upon the natural order, we learn how to roll with the ruff & tumble of a changing environment, developing a robust, bottom up culture that will thrive in, rather than survive future shock.

Anyway, hereâ€™s the mix;

Dennis Ferrer Essential Mix 27-Sep-08

& the tracklist;

DJ Yellow & Astrid Suryanto 'Light On Me (Satoshie Tomiie Remix)' (Project)

entry.title: uk house benchmark
entry.content:
crazy how the twisted salsa swing that was squeezed out of grime by MC egos and US-facing reductionism lay dormant for a while and is now re-injecting itself into Funky.

Marcus Nasty & Mak 10 on Rinse

People who are throwing the phrase "just brokenbeat" around should turn their subs up when playing the above audio.

Benchmarks for me in terms of how great this sound could be and where I'd like to see it go:

-D-Malice - Gabryelle remix - those iconic strings getting chopped up to sound like a salsa-house version of Colder = alotttt

-Hard House Banton - Sirens - like early dubstep when it was creepy not cantankerous, vibed out, minimal and hard-hitting jeep bass music

-Donaeo - African Warrior sped up to 140 bpm, sounds like a new Davinche tune!

entry.title: "I'm white, middle-class, and I like guitar music. The same goes for my readers"
entry.content:
http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2008/sep/08/race

"I'm white, middle-class, and I like guitar music. The same goes for my readers," one commissioning editor told me last year, explaining why he wasn't interested in a story about black British music. I wondered at the time why he thought it was relevant to tell me that he was white. Either way the message was clear: black people like black music, and white people like white music: guitar music. For God's sake don't tell Chuck Berry.

link.title: "I'm white, middle-class, and I like guitar music. The same goes for my readers"

entry.title: Bok Bok's birthday party / Sub.Fm / DopeGames
entry.content:
LISTENNNNNNNNNNNN UP
Night Slugs is still looking for a new home, but in the meantime we're back for a one-off special to celebrate my birthday!



My friend Georgie @ Drums Of The South has asked me to take care of her DOTS night as a one off, and we've gone and hijacked it. Downstairs @ Plan B for those that don't know is a tiny intimate space with a Funktion 1 system. This will be special. Come and celebrate with us!


*******************

Here's some audio from Sub.FM the other day when L-Vis 1990 joined me on the Night Slugs show. We played funky, old skool breakstep, bit of garage and then got down to the 4x4 and heavy bass dubs. Was a good session! Grab it here:

entry.title: the return of 7 Year Glitch
entry.content:
7YG was the fitst night to give me a DJ gig. Their open minded but rave-orientated music policy was an early inspiration for what me and the crew are doing today, and whats more 7YG were doing a mix of urban/electronic party musics in a jumbled up fashion before it was popular.

This Saturday 7 Year Glitch is back, in a slightly different guise. Now that everyone is jumping on this heavy bass ting(and don't worry, Bok Bok/Manara/Lower End Spasm are definitely sticking to ours guns) the new 7 Year Glitch is here to celebrate a less jump-up, more US-influenced side of club music.

Dan already posted the flyer bellow but lets have it again:


Here's a few trax to get you hype for this:
BOBBY KONDERS - Let There Be House
THE HOUSE MASTER BOYZ AND THE RUDE BOYZ OF HOUSE - House Nation
MIKE DUNN - So Let It Be House
DJ DEEON & DJ FUNK - Let It Be House
THE IT (LARRY HEARD) - Donnie
STARSKI & CLUTCH - Tripple Gold
DJ GREEDY - Silent Alarm
DJ DEEON - House-O-Matic
MIKE DUNN - Work That Mutha Fucka
FRANKIE KNUCKLES ft JAMIE PRINCIPLE - Baby Wants To Ride
HERCULES - 7 Ways To Jack
THE SWEAT BOYZ (ADONIS) - Do You Want To Perculate
DJ CLENT - Hit It From The Back
DJ GREEDY - Work This
DJ CLENT - Work It

Ok I think that's enough for now, you get the idea. WORK IT, JACK YOUR BODY, FALL IN LOVE, GET ON THE FLOOR AND PERCULATE with us tomorrow night at the Korsan, Dalston.


**************

In other annoucements, we're hyped for Notting Hill Carnival and we're gonna warp up for our weekend at 7YG and Carnival on the NIGHT SLUGS SHOW, 5-7pm GMT SUB.FM on Saturday afternoon.
L-Vis 1990 will join me, we're gonna play some UK house, some old skool breakstep and tons of BRAND NEW HEAVY BASS EXCLUSIVES as always.

entry.title: "don't watch wearing my rolex..."
entry.content:
the question consuming the forums in recent days is who is wiley's new tune 'where's my brother?' aimed at? who's the 'brother' that's betrayed him? is it skepta, presumptive king of grime, is it old foe lethal b, or is it god's gift, goodz, trim...

it might be all these people, but above all it's grime: "you ain't got no hits / you'll never cross overrrrr" he spits, almost sadly. wiley's proven his lyrical use of metaphysics time and again... 'i am grime', he's always said. grime is supposed to be an abstract concept, but for wil it's all too real, he feels it too deeply.

he is grime, and nan, he is london.

but now he's had enough. again:
im sorry but i aint comin back mate its over the days of me being on rinse and on endz like ive got no ambition are over if you wanna call me a sell out go ahead but i dont care its over the dream of all of us being grime stars with grime music aint yet its when ice kid and that get to 23 so just let me go and shut up please
he's quit grime again. just like he did last year. we all know from experience not to take anything he says seriously - but it doesn't stop his every mad utterance being a fascinating insight into the mind of a crazed genius. his new song 'summertime' is shit electro crossover pap, but it'll earn him the money that FAR better tracks like 'if you're going out i'm going out too' would have done if the music industry wasn't just a putrid carcass of rotting old ideas.

let's not end on a negative note though. put the superb 'where's my brother' on super-ultra-permanent repeat and come dance with us on saturday night in dalston at 7 year glitch:

entry.title: Carnival 08's biggest tune
entry.content:
With Carnival weekend fast aproaching, Silverlink's THE MESSAGE IS LOVE ft Jammer and Badness is both timely and totally fucking incredible.

160bpm soca touched by the explosive magic of vocal grime, with a blissfull hands-int-the-air breakdown in the middle. This tune is one of those epic, life-affirming moments in music that remind you why you're in this game at all.

Myself, Manara, L-Vis 1990 and Starkey among others have been banging this tune non-stop. When Jammer's 'MERKLE A GYAL' bit comes in tune gets wheeled instantly!! Usully 4 or 5 times, standard!!!!!!


Hear It here:
www.myspace.com/silverlink


Out to the No Hats No Hoods camp doing it differently

entry.title: tribal house
entry.content:
I'll post a Part 2 to Dan's epic Year So Far Part 1 when I can find a minute to get my thoughts together.

In the meantime:
A friend and I use 'tribal house' as a joke dirty word, kind of like a safe word in S&M (though not like that, NO HOMO). But Lower End Spasm has never been about snobbery and I'm thinking it might be time to think of a new word as I can't stop listening to Bongo Jam by Crazy Cousinz. I still find it a bit repulsive (whats with that style of vocals that aims to sound like the vocal Other and ends up at some sort of Latin-via-weirdsville accent??), but its totally compelling and, to be honest, kind of amazing - I can't take it off repeat.

Here's an amazing mix by Marcus Nasty that he did live on 1Xtra.
I'm vybzing to this TO NO END, not least because I can DISTINCTLY hear the influence of old grime production coming through - Marcus even plays a UK Funky remix of Pulse X at about 44:30. The combination of warm grimey bass, bongos, percussion, grimey horn stabs and minimal driving piono is so effective. Its a magic formula! Despite the slow tempo and how deceptively lukewarm Funky can sound I've seen it light up dancefloors in a totally unique way - its groove is hypnotic but eventually undeniable.
BTW marcus is calling the music 'UK House' which seems farrrrrr more pleasing than 'Funky'. I think that word is maybe the one thing that has kept me so far from embracing this sound - superficial I know, but the connotations of the 'F word' ain't good.

Here's another mix (and nice interview) by Kode9 on DJ Rupture's WFMU show in which 9 debuts some of his new UK Funky material under the new alias Frankie Solar. He describes the music as a cross between grime and soca, and apart from the tempo he's basically spot on.

I can only hope that the more inventive side of Funky continues to flourish because its young producers definitely onto something here. I know one thing though - when the ravers come back from Malia and Napa this year the UK top 40 should by right be an interesting place.

On another note, here's the video to Majuva's Township Funk, the insane 2-year old Kwaito tune that's suddenly blowing up all over the place:


I'm playing this everywhere I DJ right now. Can't get enough. Not so much 'tribal house' as a militant marching riddim - that wobbly synth cuts right through the middle of the dance and does a lot on the floor proving how sometimes its worth laying off the bass for a minute or two.


So on my way out, a nod towards The Year So Far part 2: Bassline and UK Funky in 2008, the year that house saved garage.

entry.title: The Year So Far Pt. 1
entry.content:
As 2007 tailed off into 2008 the air was ripe with musical prophesies. Chief among these was the notion that grime â€“ surely, to most listeners/observers, the most scintillating British musical evolution of the era â€“ was at the critical point, the morphing point, where its listless vitality would be diverted elsewhere, towards the next station in the continuum. This idea assumes that there is an almost-finite amount of creativity in music; that as it drains out of one genre, it supplements another, probably newer one. I wonâ€™t address the problems with that here.

As dubstep has slipped into dnbâ€™s slipstream (somewhat removed from this argument by their stable status as student floor-fillers), house dominated these prophesies of forward motion: funky, bassline, the slinkier sounds or the gullier ones, whichever you chose, they were poised to annex that area of pop culture that isnâ€™t permanently occupied by white rock â€“ the area that is available to non-guitar music, space that always has to be negotiated with its more readily marketed American cousins.

There havenâ€™t been any revolutions yet. Funkyâ€™s sonic progress creaks along in increasingly â€“ though youâ€™ve got to say slowly â€“ innovative directions, and continues to fill clubs, continues to attract interest. Everyone likes Appleâ€™s â€˜Siegalizerâ€™. Of course they do, itâ€™s great. Itâ€™s not reached The Pop Moment though, itâ€™s not the new religion. Bassline, Niche, 4x4, and its fellow bass-undulating travellers kill dancefloors, though generally they remain a midlands and northern phenomenon, despite the more nation-wide, audacious raid made on the charts by T2 et al, where they camped out for a few weeks earlier this year.



Enough pussy-footing around though: everyoneâ€™s prophesies missed something pretty vital. Hereâ€™s the question:

How did vapid electro â€“ electro that sounds like 2003â€™s pomo, plastic sword-stab at futurism â€“ suddenly become the British urban undergroundâ€™s most easy avenue into the mainstream?

Dizzeeâ€™s â€˜Dance Wiv Meâ€™, Wileyâ€™s â€˜Wearing My Rolexâ€™, Wileyâ€™s â€˜Summertimeâ€™, Tinchyâ€™s â€˜Strydermanâ€™, Skeptaâ€™s â€˜Rolex Sweepâ€™, Lethalâ€™s â€˜Keys To The Bentleyâ€™, even Godâ€™s Gift has done one for christâ€™s sake, though I canâ€™t find the rip.

They arenâ€™t uniformly massive hits, but aggregated theyâ€™ve done â€“ or are about to do â€“ astonishingly well. Itâ€™s pathetically easy to name better, grimier songs by each artist above that should have done just as well in the charts (Wiley has at least 20), that should have been just as successful as POP singles, if charts were meritocracies â€“ but therein lies the sticky issue of why the music industry doesnâ€™t like to put out good music.

Some of this arbitrary, chart-topping wave of electro has been half-decent. No more than half decent though. And perhaps, tenuously, it is part of a wider, cross-media trend, part of a series of disconnected gropes in the direction of â€˜new raveâ€™, which neatly coalesces with the twenty years rule for nostalgia cycles: there are acid house documentaries on Radio 2 this year. Radio 2.



But from grime's point of view, why electro? Why now? Why has it worked?

Meanwhile, 2008â€™s second hallmark seems to be nostalgia for a more recent era. Garage in the clubs, and grimetapes.com (and its thematic pre-thoughts, Goodzâ€™s â€˜Switching Songsâ€™ and Lewi and Smasherâ€™s â€˜Back in the Dayâ€™) high in your bookmarks seem central to this wonderfully lost period. And it is lost. While this bizarre urban pragmatism is thriving on T4 and the Radio 1 playlist, nostalgia for another grand crossover era is thriving in so many clubs. You want â€˜Flowersâ€™ or â€™21 Secondsâ€™? Of course itâ€™s in the bag, let me just cue it up...

Hereâ€™s what me and Alex were saying on gchat a couple of days ago that prompted this blog post:

Alex: this year grime is about electrohouse singles and nostalgia
Dan: so weird isn't it
i would like to read a convincing blog piece about why electro, why now, and why it's worked??
i would write it myself, but i ain't got a clue
i think it's interesting that no hc continuum theorist would EVER have predicted wiley, dizzee, skepta, even stryder breaking into the charts with weird OLD electro
Alex: i have an inkling
Dan: and this in its own way proves the dysfunctionality of the continuum
Alex: i think itâ€™s two processes at work
i wanted to write about this year in general
cos itâ€™s really weirding me out
Dan: totally
until you said 'nostalgia and electro' it hadn't occurred to me really
those are the two twin overriding themes
bloody strange
Alex: my theory on what's going on with grime crossovers
post-Topshop's idea of new rave, this country is SOOO CONFUSED
this year you have African middle aged dads on the walworth road (and tinchy stryder) wearing
katherine hamnet/house of holland ripoff Ts
so combine that with the yearning of the urban music scene to get back onto the dancefloor
x a really misguided sense of what is 'white and cool'/trendy = wiley over electrohouse
also THE THING THAT NOBODY REALISES IS
wiley is a contextual genius in terms of songwriting
Dan: yes
Alex: and wearing my rolex, clearly, was done in the same way as the streets' rave tune
Dan: hence the paucity of lyrics on rolex
Alex: itâ€™s like a snapshot of him drunk and lairy
Dan: because electro doesnâ€™t need lots of bars
Alex: in a club that he's at just to get crunk and hit on girls
hence the electro is playing in the background
itâ€™s incidental as far as iâ€™m concerned
i think its just short(long)hand for 'mainstream club' right??
but the grime scene being what it is people copycat like crazy

Watch out for part 2...

entry.title: VENOM & DAMAGE - FRENZY

As a bonus Venom is also giving away this original track @ 320. Up for a limited time only so grab it quick:
DJ VENOM & DAMAGE - Love In The Club


Catch Venom alongside myself b2b Jack Latham (aka Mr Charisma b2b Jam City aka the Lower End Spas clash the world has been waiting for) playing jacking ghetto house here:

entry.title: K-SWIFT RIP

more info here



damn

entry.title: roundup
entry.content:
all the new shit riiiight here, lets get down to it.



SUB FM are ahead of the game with some new moves in the technology department. Firstly every set in archive.subfm.com will now appear in the new Sub FM podcast, so subscribe to the feed and never miss a thing:
http://archive.subfm.com/podcast.php

Also - introducing SUB FM MOBILE, for your BlackBerry, Nokia, SonyEricsson, Motorola, Siemens, SX1, BenQ, Arima, Sendo X and soon the iPhone too.
While Sub lives up to its "pirate-style" claims with its format and content, its status as an online streaming-only station has always limited it from reaching the realms that a real pirate station should - the car system, the bus, the classroom, the workplace. This new move totally changes everything, alowing the Sub single to emanate far and wide.

Here's my latest SUB FM set from this satruday:
BOK BOK - SUB FM NIGHT SLUGS SHOW 12-07-08.
Its 2 hours of pure dubs and a couple of classics classics, featuring trax from Sticky, MRK1, Spookz, DJ Klassic, Joker, Screama, Matt Shadetek, Jakes, Drop The Lime, Illmana, Starkey, Nevamiss, 2nd II None, J-Sweet, Burgaboy, A Dot R, L-Vis 1990, Merkury, Moves!!!, DS1, Cardopusher, Dubchild, Bogeyman, Subzero, Dexplicit.
The last 20 minutes or so I'm introducing my new side project Mr Charisma with a jackin ghetto house mix. Watch out for more on both Bok Bok and Charisma fronts v v soon.



***********************************



The good people over at The Heatwave present a new club night that they describe as Caribbean Rave, in other words bashment, funky house, soca, garage, bassline & jungle, in other words TROPICAL BASS!!!!!!! which is right up our street.

The launch party is THIS SATURDAY:


To celebrate, here's a mix they've done:

Gabriel Heatwave & Ben Dubstar - Immediate Sounds Vol 1

tracklist:
1. Beenie Man & So Solid Crew - Yagga Yo
2. Ms Dynamite & Menta - Ramp
3. El-B - Shorty (Steppas Remix)
4. Glamour Murphy - What The Woman Want (Acapella)
5. QQ - Screechie
6. Stacy - Let Meh Know
7. Kyla & Paleface - Do You Mind (Crazy Cousins Remix)
8. Geeneus & Zinc - I Try (Instrumental)
9. Vybz Kartel - Stop Gwaan Stush (Acapella)
10. Top Cat & Double 99 - Ripgroove
11. Durrty Goodz - Pum Pum Stealer
12. Tubby - Turbo Shandy
13. Destra & Dizzee Rascal - Flex (Tim Turbo Refix)
14. Plastic Gangsters - Rock To The Rhythm
15. Shabba Ranks - Love Punaany Bad (Baby G Remix)
16. Elephant Man - Nobody Nobody
17. Notch - Nuttin' Nuh Go So (RCola Remix)18. Soundclash feat Red Fox & Screechie Dan - Pum Pum Shorts

yep yep



***********************************



The Patchwork Pirates show you how to make a solid mixtape. Big selection, tight blends and huge sound @ 320kbps:

Patchwork Pirates - FabricLive Promo Mix

tracklist:
1. Joker - 'Snake Eater'
2. Twista - 'Pimp Like Me'
3. Benga - 'Crunked Up'
4. Stylo-G Ft. Icekid & Sickman - 'My Yout'
5. Sukh Knight - 'Born Invincible'
6. Wonder - 'God's Gift Intro'
7. Dr Dre Ft. Eminem - 'Forgot About Dre' (Kraddy Remix) 8. The Colonel - 'Ruckus'
9. edIT - 'The Game Is Not Over'
10. Hovatron - 'Made You Look'
11. Modeselektor - 'Hasir'
12. Cabin Bwoy - 'Flip Mode Selektor'



***********************************



Patchwork Pirates are at Fabric this friday alongside Starkey the Starkbot (and others), but I have to say come to CHOCKABLOCK instead cos WE'RE PLAYING IT:

entry.title: Weekend sounds
entry.content:
Chocking some more Block down at The Egg on Friday with Bok Bok and Manara, courtesy of Observer cover star JP. Friday also features, excitingly, a performance from Pres T - a fans' favourite whose live appearances are all too rare. 'This Likkle Yout' and 'Large Way' are two largely unrecognised classics - President has that same kind of rhythmically flatlining delivery that has seen Trim hailed as a poet-messiah.

Pres T - Large Way (Sendspace)

He makes other MCs look like toasted ham and cheese, apparently.



Meanwhile the Heatwave boys have a new night on in Stokey called Immediate Sounds, which should to be the usual upbeat party vibes judging by previous Heatwave raves. If you don't know what to expect, a preview mix that features everyone from El-B to Shabba to Paleface ought to sort you out. Skanking ting!

In other news, who else read that there's a Sidewinder planned for LONDON in December??? Let's hope Sidewinder management are preparing the mountains of paperwork they will have to do for the Met already - and if you don't know why it counts as BIG NEWS that a substantial grime rave is being planned for London, then you obviously haven't read Woofah 2 yet, in which case you need to get it before it's too late.

Also, FWD hosts a Pay As U Go reunion in August?!?! Some retro thrills right there. I seem to remember the words Spyro and Mac 10 being mentioned in close proximity on the flyer too.

entry.title: out to Deep Time
entry.content:
Props to Deeptime on posting this quote:
The scam of scams was always the Olympics: Berlin in 1936 to Beijing in 2008. Engines of regeneration. Orgies of lachrymose nationalism. War by other means. Warrior-athletes watched, from behind dark glasses, by men in suits and uniforms. The pharmaceutical frontline. Rogue Californian chemists running their eye-popping, vein-clustered, vest-stripping robots against degendered state laboratory freaks. Bearded ladies and teenage girls who never have periods. Medals returned by disgraced drug cheats to be passed on to others who werenâ€™t caught, that time. The Millennium Dome fiasco was a low-rent rehearsal. The holy grail for blue-sky thinkers was the sport-transcends-politics Olympiad, the five-hooped golden handcuffs, the smoke rings behind which deals could be done for casinos and malls: with corporate sponsorship, flag-waving and infinitely elastic budgets (any challenge an act of naysaying treason).

Come 2012 I'm OUT OF HERE

entry.title: NYC was a lot
entry.content:
Excuse the self-centered post, I thought I'd say some stuff about NYC.
Not really feeling being back. I had to really think hard on the way home about the things that make this country/city unique and worth living in - our rave heritage and 1away urban dance scene, our comparatively integrated society etc etc whilst trying not to think about our cultural stigmas, overpriced food and shitty transport system.

Anyway here's some digested highlights for youse!!!!!

Rowdy was tiny but cosy and the crowd really made the vibe complete. Out to the galdem who were shouting all the bars to Duppy when we played the instrumental.
Here's us doin itttt:

Listen out for Luca DTL humming Night really loud in the background. I kept thinking someone was mixing it in!

Here's Starkey, who absolutely killed it as always. Check out the first tune, called Pictures by Starkbot himself, its amongst my top riddims of the moment.


Here's Dev79. Check me out taking photos in this vid, I look retarded.



Out to Secret Agent Gel,Black Plague, Shani and the whole crew - we had a great night!




Out to our best buddy Kingdom!!!! The Club Vortex Heavy Bass special went off! The crowd was almost exclusively made up of beautifully-dressed teenage homo thugs, which did a lot for us despite them ripping the club appart over the course of the night. Kuduro drumz, 8 bit synths and rave stabs had the biggest impact, provoking chanting and formation dances.
A hightlight of the night is vocalist Shyvonne performing her brand new track MIND READER over Kingdom's BANG riddim.
Here's a video of half the PA, before the camera battery ran out. Lol + me on the introduction:

This is gonna be the first US BASSLINE hit, mark my words. It's like a US Might Be. We're still waiting for Kingdom to record the final vocal and mix that shit down, but watch this space for more on that one.



DJ Rupture kindly asked me and Manara to come on his radio show on WFMU which was a great honour. We talked (maybe a bit too much) about grime past, bassline present and international heavy bass future and played some tunes.

More details and streamable archive of the show here.


We randomly got to see Todd the Godd Edwards and DJ Blaqstarr DJing in a very small, innocuous bar on the Lower East Side. It was wierd. Apparently Todd Edwards hasn't played in NYC in years.

Todd played exclusively his own material, had a jolly smile on his face the whole time (I think maybe his music is the polar opposite to 'showa'). He was largely ignored by the kids in the bar except for us and a few die hards who did their thing on the flo'. When I approached him he thanked me profusely for coming.

Blaqstarr seems to be learning from uncle Diplo cos he's turned into an amazing alround party DJ, playing everything from dancehall classix to fidget and pulling it off with charisma. He even dropped Heartbroken (apparently its Blaqstarr and Rye Rye's favourite tune of the moment) and we got it rewound which felt great but also weird.

We also saw Blaqstarr do his banging stripped down baltimore thing at Dante's Fried Chicken which is like a daytime cookout party. GUNIT played it too and killed it! The best thing about this party is that there were kids there that wouldn't stop dancing! It was sooooooooooooo amazing to watch:

There's nothing like watching kids go nuts to Samir's Theme SERIOUSLY.
The vibe at this event really warmed my heart.



Lastly - TROUBLE & BASS!!!! We played just before going home. This is NYC's hypest, most upfront party. Here's Dubchild going way off the scale:


The whole of the back wall of Love club's dancefloor is one giant sub, it's actually stupid. Although after numerous noise complains they've apparently been keeping the volume kind of low. It took a while for the system to really get warm, but by the time Dubchild was merking like in the above video, we were wading in bass! Love is insane.


Externally it might seem like T&B's music policy is the same as our one at Night Slugs, but really they've managed to meld together a load of disperate sounds in a way that is surprisingly cohesive. Sort of goth-via-bmore, jungle and electro-into bassline house, all mixed up with cyberpunk imagery and a jump-up ethic. They're the only crew that can make me enjoy electrohouse bangorz being dropped in a dark, bassy rave sort of way, Mixes in with plenty of dubstep and bassline house. Killer selections all round!
and DUBCHILD has really got his own very original sound going on, even when making dubstep. I really prefer his insane alien melodies and wonky, banging trax 100% over all the modern Rusko-baiting sludge in the dubstep genre [went to Fabric recently, and with the notable exceptions of DTL everyone there just played thattype of dubstep and fidget house all night long, how come everyone's playing bassy shit in big rooms at peak time nowadays? Wierd]

We came on right after Drop The Lime - so tough an act to follow!
My first tune got wheeled - How does a US night end up with Smelly by Bogeyman as their standard anthem??? I dropped that without even knowing and everyone wents nuts. We just played our smoothest craziest bassline shit and all of Starkey's new stuff. The T&B crowd is probably the noisiest of the US crowds we played to, but still they don't scream and shout like UK ravers. We *think* it went off, but if you were there than hola @ us. Here some pix:




Out to Kingdom, Drop The Lime, Mathhead, The Captain, Star Eyes, Secret Agent Gel, Black Plague, Starkey, Peter Gun, DJ Rupture, Matt Shadetek (next time bro), Haldan & The Palms Out crew, Denny Le Nimh and AC Slater and everybody who came out to see us play. We'll be back soon as we can!!!!!

entry.title: My Fellow Americans book / Rap music needs Barack
entry.content:
Just a little bit of a heads-up. Myself and my artist buddy Tom Humberstone have produced a book about our travels around the US Presidential Election during Jan and Feb this year, meeting the candidates, vampires, Vietnam vets, and redneck weirdos who told us we were godless. Our words and pictures, bigged up in The Times, The Guardian, Dazed&Confused, New Statesman, the BBC (in the form of a ten minute interview!), and all over the web, are available in a limited-edition numbered first print run here via paypal or card. More info on the blog, www.myfellowamericans2008.com.


I was going to upload Mavado's 'On The Rock' refix We Need Barack, but Mavado's voice has tipped over from its captivating, emotionally-strained state into pained on that one. It actually hurts at points. In any case the line about politicians from the original - 'dem mek a bag a promise and nah fulfil none' - quite perfectly sums up millions of young America's fears - and in a way, their hopes - about Obama, in our experience travelling through 24 states of the USA.

Nas - Black President
http://www.sendspace.com/file/amkcbq

You're better off with Nas's 'Black President'. I fully expect every rapper in the US to have a tune out about Obama by November. What I want to know is why America's hip-hop bigwigs weren't talking about the election earlier? There have been so many songs about black presidents in the past, did everyone lose interest when the real thing became a possibility? Only Chuck D was on this from the beginning, albeit he wanted Obama as Hillary's VP.

link.title: My Fellow Americans book / Rap music needs Barack
